text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Former prime minister Tansu Ciller is hoping to win the support of voters from the Islamist Welfare Party, her partner in the previous government.
- A leading businessmen says banks are deceiving the public with inflated profit figures.
- Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz says in an interview he expects the Islamist Welfare Party to split up after its loss of power.
- Economy officials say preparations are being made on a draft law to regulate public borrowing.
- Twenty-five police officers are injured in a protest by Islamists after Friday prayers in Istanbul.
- The energy minister has ordered an investigation into charges connected with a tender made by electricity company TEDAS.
- An article of the secularist education bill is rejected because of opposition to plans for the religious directorate to control religious education.
- President Suleyman Demirel criticises protesters who demonstrated after Friday prayers.
- The level of manufacturing capacity utilisation falls in July to 80.4 percent from 82 percent in May.
- A state minister says Turkey will play a leading role in the Turkic republics of central Asia.
